qas.question: Where had Paymasters been able to get money from directly until 1782?
After 1782, where would money from Paymasters' withdrawal requests go?
Whose administration repealed the Paymaster General Act?
When was the Paymaster General Act passed?
When did Paymasters begin to get money directly from the HM treasury?
Who could no longer make withdrawal requests to the Bank of England after 1782?
How often could paymasters make withdrawals?
Which administration proposed the Paymaster act?
The Paymaster Act allowed Paymasters to withdraw funds from what source at their own discretion?

context: The Paymaster General Act <a3_0><b4_0>1782<b4_0/><a3_0/> ended the post as a lucrative sinecure. Previously, <b5_0>Paymasters<b5_0/> had been able to draw on money from <a0_0><b8_0>HM Treasury<b8_0/><a0_0/> at their discretion. Now they were required to put the money they had requested to withdraw from the Treasury into <a1_0>the Bank of England<a1_0/>, from where it was to be withdrawn for specific purposes. The Treasury would receive <b6_0>monthly<b6_0/> statements of the Paymaster's balance at the Bank. This act was repealed by <a2_0><b7_0>Shelburne<a2_0/>'s<b7_0/> administration, but the act that replaced it repeated verbatim almost the whole text of the Burke Act.
